ygData.subject: Re: Time series framework
ygData.msgSnippet: Hey Tom, Sounds like you are trying to use the ANN for decision making and not strictly time-series. But that doesn t really matter. IMHO it sounds like you

Hey Tom,

Sounds like you are trying to use the ANN for decision making and=
 not
strictly time-series. But that doesn't really matter. IMHO it sounds
l=
ike you are trying to get it to do too much: "one output that indicates
the=
 optimal action and conviction". I have not built a billion dollar
trading =
system but if it was me I would scale it back a bit. There is a
lot of inte=
lligence needed to even guess if the market is going to move
up or down in =
the next five minutes. Much less to make complex trading
strategy decisions=
. I would maybe try and break the problem into parts.

Is the market bid pr=
ice going to move up or down?
Is the market ask price going to move up or d=
own?
Is the market bid volume going to move up or down?
Is the market ask v=
olume going to move up or down?
Is bid price going to be higher than ask pr=
ice?
etc.....

I bet you can use time-series analysis for the above type of=
 problems.
Though I am sure it won't be a trivial. Then use the resulting A=
NNs as
input into a decision making network(s).  Maybe try and dissect the
=
decision making problem into other decision making problems. Plus I
would p=
robably look at some of the  research into incremental evolution.
Try and s=
lowly evolve up the complexity of the problem and the
intelligence of the n=
etwork  by starting with simpler problems.

Additionally maybe start by gai=
ning expertise in another domain of
decision making problems. One where you=
 have more control before moving
onto the stock market. One thing about the=
 stock market is that you
don't have any control over it and anything can h=
appen. So it isn't a
very controlled environment for experiments. So even i=
f you evolve a
network that deals very well with one set of data or even se=
veral. These
sets might not be indicative of the behavior of future markets=
.  For my
time series work I am investing much simpler well researched/docu=
mented
problems and trying to understand them. Before moving on to
incremen=
tally more complex problems.

> Do you learn over various time windows to r=
emove specific window bias?
>
Right now I am learning over just one time wi=
ndow. The number of inputs
I am using is huge already. So I down want to in=
crease them. But I am
thinking of looking into that. But because I am using=
 a recurrent
network, the network itself can develop a sort of rudimentary =
memory
that allows it to improve its prediction based on the previous patte=
rns
presented. To see a very basic example of this solve for the two input
=
xor problem with recurrent links enabled. If you take the resulting
network=
 and present the four training patterns to it in the same order
as during t=
raining it will produce the correct output. If you start
mixing up the orde=
r of the patterns then you will get totally different
outputs. This is beca=
use the net has either learned the order of the
patterns and is using its m=
emory to say I just saw pattern X so X+1 must
be next. Or it is using some =
other aspect of the previous pattern to
produce its next output. Either way=
 it has developed a memory of the
preceding event(s) that it is using to pr=
oduce its results for the
current event.

Don't know if that is any help bu=
t those are my verbose opinions on the
matter.

Thanks,

Shane


--- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, "Thomas McCallum" <termcc@...> wrote:
>
> I have done th=
e same thing under NEAT and rtNEAT using the C++
> version. I have not been=
 able to get particularly good results though
> from it.  My scenario is be=
low, perhaps you could compare it to yours
> and tell me if how it differs.=

>
> Set of inputs e.g. close, open high, low, f(close), g(close) etc
> Tar=
get output e.g. a real number indicating the optimal action and
conviction.=

>
> Results:  A huge variance in results ( seems to destory good networks)=

> with the best only reaching 76%.
> A known 96% network is a time-recurre=
nt network with 1 hidden layer
> with 2 nodes.
>
> Do you learn over variou=
s time windows to remove specific window bias?
>
> I have not tried variabl=
e mutation rates, but am happy to discuss
> avenues for this application.
>=

> Tom
>
> On 3/20/07, shanemcdonaldryan shanemcdonaldryan@... wrote:
> > H=
i,
> >
> > I am in the midst of building a times series predicting framewor=
k
> > based on Matt Buckland's windows c++ code.
> >
> > I've removed the v=
isualization aspects.
> >
> > Made it compile under windows and Linux (the =
same code runs 250%
> > faster under Linux BTW).
> >
> > Made a generalized=
 framework for loading time series patterns from a
file.
> >
> > It is quit=
e rough and undocumented but it allows you to simply edit
a
> > parameter f=
ile and present patterns to do time-series prediction
using
> > NEAT. I thi=
nk it is also quite fast and I have some plans that I
will
> > elucidate on=
 in my next message that could significantly speed it
up.
> >
> > I've also=
 built a little tool to run the saved result network and
> > generate a CSV=
 file. So you can load the times series as a graph in
> > excel and visuali=
ze the results of your networks prediction compared
> > to the original tim=
e series.
> >
> > It has plenty of work that needs done on it. But I figure=
d I might
> > create a Sourceforge page and post it if anyone is interested=
?
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Shane
